"Valkyrie" is a gripping historical drama that unfolds against the backdrop of World War II. Directed by Bryan Singer, this film delivers a tense and suspenseful narrative that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

Tom Cruise gives a solid performance as Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg, a German officer who becomes involved in a plot to assassinate Adolf Hitler. Cruise brings depth and complexity to his character, capturing Stauffenberg's determination and inner conflict. His portrayal is both compelling and believable, making it easy for the audience to root for him throughout the film.

The supporting cast, including Kenneth Branagh, Bill Nighy, and Tom Wilkinson, delivers strong performances that add another layer of intensity to the story. Each actor brings their A-game to their respective roles, ensuring that every character feels important and well-developed.

One of the highlights of "Valkyrie" is its attention to detail and production design. The film seamlessly recreates the era, immersing the audience in the grim reality of Nazi Germany. The set pieces, costumes, and cinematography all contribute to the film's authentic aesthetic, enhancing the overall experience.

The pacing of the film is expertly handled, with tension building steadily as the plot unravels. The script keeps the audience engaged throughout, revealing the various challenges faced by the conspirators and the high stakes involved in their mission. The film doesn't rely on action sequences to create suspense but instead builds tension through its captivating narrative and well-developed characters.

While some critics may argue that the film lacks emotional depth or fails to explore certain aspects in detail, "Valkyrie" remains a riveting and thought-provoking historical drama. It sheds light on a lesser-known chapter of World War II history and highlights the bravery of those who dared to resist Hitler's regime from within.

In conclusion, "Valkyrie" is a compelling war drama that successfully combines historical accuracy, intense performances, and a captivating storyline. It is a must-watch for fans of WWII films, as well as those who appreciate thought-provoking stories and solid acting.

"The Witch" is a hauntingly atmospheric, slow-burn horror film that tests the patience of its audience while rewarding them with an eerie and deeply unsettling experience. Director Robert Eggers crafts a masterful portrayal of 17th-century New England, immersing viewers in a world plagued by paranoia and religious fanaticism.

One of the film's greatest achievements is its meticulous attention to detail. From the costumes and set design to the authentic dialogue, every aspect contributes to the authenticity and sense of historical accuracy. This commitment to historical realism strengthens the film's ability to immerse viewers in a bygone era and adds a layer of credibility to the story.

The standout performances by the entire cast deserve applause. Anya Taylor-Joy delivers a mesmerizing performance as Thomasin, a young girl caught in a downward spiral of suspicion and fear. Her emotional journey is portrayed with exceptional skill and nuance, making her character sympathetic and relatable despite the bizarre circumstances.

"The Witch" is not a film that relies on cheap scares and jump scares. Instead, Eggers employs a slow-building tension that gradually escalates throughout the film, creating an unnerving atmosphere that lingers long after the credits roll. The eerie musical score and the stunning cinematography further contribute to the film's oppressive mood, leaving the audience on edge and constantly guessing.

While some may find the deliberate pacing of the film frustrating, it ultimately serves a purpose. The deliberate slow burn allows the tension to simmer, generating a sense of impending doom that adds weight to the unsettling climax. This may not be a film for those seeking instant gratification and gore, but for those willing to invest in a thought-provoking and psychologically chilling experience, "The Witch" is a true gem.

In conclusion, "The Witch" is a shining example of a horror film that relies on atmosphere, storytelling, and exceptional performances to create genuine fear and unease. It is a thought-provoking exploration of religious extremism, paranoia, and the supernatural that will leave you haunted long after the film ends. Though it may not be for everyone, those with a taste for atmospheric horror will find themselves enthralled by this dark and unsettling tale.

"Ed Wood" is a biographical film by Tim Burton that delves into the eccentric life and career of the titular cult filmmaker. Johnny Depp gives a mesmerizing performance as Ed Wood, capturing his enthusiasm, determination, and unwavering love for making movies. From the get-go, the film immerses you in the endearing world of Ed Wood, blending reality with fantasy and showcasing Wood's relentless pursuit of his creative vision.

What makes "Ed Wood" truly shine is its perfect blend of drama and humor. The script by Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski strikes a delicate balance, delivering poignant moments while never taking itself too seriously. The movie treats Wood's ambition and passion with the utmost respect, even when his directorial skills are questionable at best. It celebrates the outsiders, the dreamers, and the underdogs in a way that is both touching and hilarious.

Tim Burton's signature dark and quirky style is on full display in "Ed Wood." The film is a visual treat with its stunning black and white cinematography by Stefan Czapsky. The attention to detail in recreating the 1950s era, from the costumes to the set designs, is impeccable. Burton's direction captures the essence of Wood's low-budget, outsider filmmaking in a way that's both nostalgic and reverential.

The supporting cast is also top-notch, with standout performances from Martin Landau as the faded horror icon Bela Lugosi and Sarah Jessica Parker as Wood's girlfriend. Landau's portrayal of Lugosi is masterful, perfectly capturing the actor's addiction struggles and his complicated friendship with Wood. Landau's performance earned him a well-deserved Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor.

"Ed Wood" is not your typical biopic. It goes beyond simply recounting Wood's questionable directorial career, delving into his personal life, relationships, and struggles. It explores themes of perseverance, creativity, and the power of following one's passion in the face of adversity. Despite the inherent eccentricity of Wood's films, there is an undeniable charm and warmth to his character that the film beautifully captures.

Overall, "Ed Wood" is a delightful and heartfelt tribute to an unconventional filmmaker who defied the odds and left a lasting mark on cinema. It's a captivating exploration of the human desire to create and the power of embracing one's quirks and uniqueness. With its excellent performances, stunning visuals, and poignant storytelling, "Ed Wood" is a must-watch for both fans of Tim Burton and lovers of offbeat cinema.

In Bruges is a dark comedy that takes viewers on a thrilling and unexpected journey through the picturesque city of Bruges, Belgium. The film follows two hitmen, Ray (Colin Farrell) and Ken (Brendan Gleeson), who are sent to Bruges by their boss after a job goes wrong. What initially seems like a simple assignment to lay low and wait for further instructions quickly turns into a complex and morally ambiguous situation.

One of the standout aspects of In Bruges is its unique blend of humor and darkness. The film manages to balance moments of laugh-out-loud comedy with intense and thought-provoking scenes. The witty and sharp dialogue, combined with the brilliant performances by Farrell and Gleeson, make for a captivating and entertaining watch.

The setting of Bruges itself plays a significant role in the film. Director Martin McDonagh beautifully captures the city's medieval architecture and tranquil canals, creating a stark contrast to the violent and chaotic events that unfold. The cinematography is stunning, with each shot meticulously framed to highlight the city's beauty and add depth to the story.

The supporting cast also delivers exceptional performances. Ralph Fiennes shines as the menacing and unpredictable boss, while Clémence Poésy brings a touch of vulnerability and mystery to her role as a local woman who befriends Ray. The chemistry between the actors is palpable, adding another layer of complexity to the already intricate plot.

In Bruges is not your typical crime thriller. It delves into themes of guilt, redemption, and the consequences of one's actions. The film raises thought-provoking questions about morality and the nature of forgiveness, leaving viewers with much to ponder long after the credits roll.

Overall, In Bruges is a masterfully crafted film that seamlessly blends dark humor, stunning visuals, and compelling performances. It is a must-watch for fans of crime dramas and those looking for a unique and thought-provoking cinematic experience.

Cross of Iron is a gripping war film that takes a unique perspective on World War II. Directed by Sam Peckinpah, the movie follows a group of German soldiers on the Eastern Front as they fight against the Soviet Union. What sets this film apart from other war movies is its focus on the German perspective, offering a different viewpoint on the conflict.

The performances in Cross of Iron are outstanding. James Coburn delivers a powerful performance as Sergeant Steiner, a battle-hardened soldier who questions the purpose of the war. Coburn brings depth and complexity to his character, making him relatable and sympathetic. The rest of the cast also shines, with strong performances from Maximilian Schell, James Mason, and David Warner.

The action sequences in the film are intense and realistic. Peckinpah's direction captures the chaos and brutality of war, immersing the audience in the gritty and violent world of the Eastern Front. The battle scenes are well-choreographed and visually stunning, showcasing the horrors of war without glorifying them.

One of the strengths of Cross of Iron is its exploration of the psychological toll of war. The film delves into the effects of combat on the soldiers, highlighting the trauma and emotional struggles they face. This adds a layer of depth to the story, making it more than just a typical war film.

The cinematography and production design are also noteworthy. The film's gritty and realistic visuals create an immersive atmosphere, transporting the audience to the war-torn landscapes of the Eastern Front. The attention to detail in the costumes and sets further enhances the authenticity of the film.

While Cross of Iron may not be as well-known as other war movies, it is a hidden gem that deserves recognition. It offers a fresh perspective on World War II and explores the human side of war in a thought-provoking way. With its strong performances, intense action sequences, and compelling storytelling, Cross of Iron is a must-watch for fans of war films.

Blade Runner is a true sci-fi classic that has stood the test of time. Ridley Scott's visually stunning masterpiece is a thought-provoking and atmospheric film that takes place in a dystopian future where genetically engineered beings known as Replicants are hunted down by Blade Runners. The performances, particularly by Harrison Ford and Rutger Hauer, are exceptional and bring depth to their characters.

The film's theme of identity and what it means to be human is explored through the interactions between the Replicants and the Blade Runners. The moral ambiguity throughout the movie raises questions about the nature of humanity and the blurred lines between man and machine. The dark and rainy Los Angeles depicted on screen is a character on its own, creating a haunting and immersive atmosphere that adds to the film's overall brilliance.

One of the most striking aspects of Blade Runner is its visual design. The neo-noir aesthetic with its futuristic noir elements creates a unique and captivating world. The production design, set pieces, and special effects are all top-notch, creating a visually stunning experience that still holds up to this day.

The slow-paced narrative might not be for everyone, but it perfectly serves the film's purpose. Blade Runner is a film that demands and rewards multiple viewings. Every time you watch it, you discover new layers and themes that enrich the experience. The philosophical questions it poses stay with you long after the credits roll.

The movie's soundtrack by Vangelis is iconic and enhances the film's atmosphere. The haunting and melancholic score perfectly complements the visuals, creating an otherworldly and ethereal ambiance.

Blade Runner is not a typical sci-fi action movie, but a piece of art that pushes the boundaries of the genre. It is a captivating and thought-provoking film that delves into existential questions while delivering a visually stunning experience. Its influence on cinema is undeniable, and it is rightfully considered one of the greatest sci-fi films of all time. If you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and experience this masterpiece.

"The Legend of Bagger Vance" is a beautifully crafted film that combines elements of sports, spirituality, and personal growth. Directed by Robert Redford, this movie tells the story of a down-and-out golfer, Rannulph Junuh (played by Matt Damon), who is given a second chance at redemption.

The film is set in the 1930s during the Great Depression, and the cinematography perfectly captures the era's atmosphere. The lush green golf courses and the stunning landscapes of Savannah, Georgia, create a visually stunning backdrop for the story. The attention to detail in the production design and costumes further enhance the authenticity of the time period.

The performances in this film are outstanding. Matt Damon delivers a nuanced and heartfelt performance as Junuh, a once-promising golfer who lost his swing and his confidence after serving in World War I. Will Smith shines as Bagger Vance, a mysterious caddy who appears out of nowhere to guide Junuh back to his true self. Smith brings a quiet wisdom and charm to the role, making Bagger Vance a memorable and enigmatic character.

The supporting cast is equally impressive. Charlize Theron portrays Adele Invergordon, a strong-willed woman who is determined to save her family's golf course from financial ruin. Theron brings depth and vulnerability to her character, making her more than just a love interest for Junuh. Jack Lemmon also delivers a touching performance as an elderly version of Junuh, reflecting on his past and the lessons he learned from Bagger Vance.

The story itself is a powerful metaphor for life's challenges and the importance of finding one's true purpose. Through the game of golf, Junuh learns to overcome his inner demons and regain his self-belief. The film explores themes of redemption, self-discovery, and the power of mentorship, all wrapped in a heartwarming and inspiring narrative.

"The Legend of Bagger Vance" is not just a sports movie; it is a thought-provoking and uplifting film that will resonate with audiences long after the credits roll. It reminds us that sometimes, all we need is a little guidance and belief in ourselves to overcome the obstacles in our lives. With its stunning visuals, exceptional performances, and profound message, this film is a true gem that deserves to be seen and appreciated.

"10 Things I Hate About You" is a delightful and refreshing teen romantic comedy that stands the test of time. Released in 1999, this film takes inspiration from William Shakespeare's "The Taming of the Shrew" and brings it into the modern era with a clever and witty script.

The story revolves around two sisters, Kat and Bianca Stratford, who couldn't be more different. Kat (played by Julia Stiles) is a strong-willed and independent feminist, while Bianca (played by Larisa Oleynik) is the popular and boy-crazy younger sister. Their overprotective father sets a rule that Bianca can only date if Kat does, leading to a hilarious and heartwarming plot.

The standout performances in this film come from the talented cast. Julia Stiles shines as the rebellious and intelligent Kat, delivering her lines with a perfect balance of sarcasm and vulnerability. Heath Ledger, in one of his breakout roles, plays Patrick Verona, the bad boy with a heart of gold who is hired to woo Kat. Ledger's charisma and charm make him instantly likable, and his chemistry with Stiles is palpable.

The supporting cast also deserves praise, with Joseph Gordon-Levitt as the lovable and determined Cameron, and David Krumholtz as the hilarious and scene-stealing Michael. The ensemble cast works together seamlessly, creating a believable and endearing group of characters.

What sets "10 Things I Hate About You" apart from other teen comedies is its smart and witty writing. The dialogue is sharp and filled with clever one-liners that still hold up today. The film also tackles important themes such as feminism, individuality, and the complexities of teenage relationships, making it more than just a typical romantic comedy.

The direction by Gil Junger is solid, capturing the essence of high school life and the emotions that come with it. The film's soundtrack is also worth mentioning, featuring iconic songs from the late 90s that perfectly complement the story and add to the overall enjoyment of the film.

Overall, "10 Things I Hate About You" is a timeless and enjoyable film that continues to resonate with audiences of all ages. Its strong performances, witty writing, and heartfelt story make it a must-watch for fans of romantic comedies and coming-of-age films. Whether you're a fan of Shakespeare or simply looking for a feel-good movie, this film is sure to leave you with a smile on your face.

"The Longest Yard" is a classic sports comedy that blends humor, action, and a heartfelt story. The film centers around Paul Crewe, played brilliantly by Adam Sandler, a former football player who finds himself in prison. The movie takes an unexpected turn when Crewe is approached by the prison's warden to assemble a team of inmates to play against the prison guards in a game of football. 

The film does a fantastic job of balancing the comedic moments with the more serious themes of friendship and redemption. The chemistry between the inmates is palpable, and their camaraderie drives the story forward. Standout performances from Chris Rock and Burt Reynolds add an extra layer of depth to the film, making it more than just a typical sports comedy.

The football sequences are thrilling, intense, and expertly shot. The action on the field is fast-paced and keeps you on the edge of your seat. Additionally, the movie does a great job of capturing the atmosphere of prison life, creating a gritty and realistic backdrop for the story.

What sets "The Longest Yard" apart from other sports comedies is its ability to tackle serious issues in an entertaining and engaging way. It explores themes of justice, corruption, and the power of teamwork. The film also poses questions about the nature of redemption and second chances, adding an emotional resonance to the plot.

Overall, "The Longest Yard" is a highly entertaining and well-crafted film. It successfully mixes humor, action, and heart to create a truly enjoyable movie-watching experience. Whether you're a sports fan or not, this film has something for everyone. Highly recommended."

A haunting and captivating piece of horror cinema, "It" is a thrilling adaptation of Stephen King's terrifying novel. Directed by Andy Muschietti, this film successfully captures the essence of fear and delivers a spine-chilling experience from start to finish.

Set in the small town of Derry, the story follows a group of misfit kids, known as the Losers' Club, who come face-to-face with Pennywise the Clown, a shape-shifting entity that preys on their deepest fears. Muschietti masterfully brings King's iconic story to life, skillfully balancing suspense, jump scares, and psychological horror.

One of the film's biggest strengths is its exceptional ensemble cast, particularly the young actors who portray the Losers' Club. Each member brings their character to life with authenticity and charm, making it easy to become emotionally invested in their journey. Standout performances include Jaeden Martell as the determined Bill Denbrough and Sophia Lillis as the fearless Beverly Marsh.

Another element that sets "It" apart is its stellar production design. The town of Derry is wonderfully realized, with a palpable sense of danger lurking in every corner. The attention to detail in the sets and costumes immerses the audience in the eerie atmosphere of the story, effectively enhancing the overall sense of dread.

The film's score, composed by Benjamin Wallfisch, is haunting and unsettling, perfectly complementing the tension on screen. From the iconic opening notes to the heart-pounding climaxes, the music adds an additional layer of intensity to the already terrifying narrative.

"It" isn't just a straightforward horror film; it also delves into themes of friendship, loss, and overcoming one's fears. The emotional depth added to the characters, as well as their backstories, creates a more profound connection between the audience and the story.

While "It" is undeniably frightening, it's not without its flaws. At times, the pacing feels slightly uneven, with certain scenes dragging on longer than necessary. Additionally, some character arcs and plot developments may feel underdeveloped, leaving a desire for more depth and exposition.

Nevertheless, "It" remains a standout horror film that successfully revitalizes the genre. With exceptional performances, stunning visuals, and a chilling atmosphere, this film will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Whether you're a fan of King's work or simply looking for a well-crafted scare, "It" delivers.

As a fan of the 21 Jump Street movies, I knew I would enjoy this comedy featuring two of the stars of that franchise, and I wasn't disappointed. This movie features a hilarious performance by Cameron Diaz, who is well-paired with co-star Jason Segel, who plays the immature and uncouth teacher Mr. Calvin. Both Diaz and Segel are surrounded by a strong supporting cast, including Molly Sims, who plays the school's principal, and Dallas Roberts, who plays the school's creepy counselor. The movie follows the misadventures of Ms. Diaz's character, who is planning to retire from teaching and use the money from her retirement account to finance a life of luxury in the Philippines. The humor is frequently crude and often borders on being inappropriate, but it's generally funny. The movie doesn't break any new ground, but it features enough laughs and charm to make it worth watching.

While watching Blood Diamond, I couldn't help but think that this story would have been better suited for a mini-series, because there's entirely too much going on here. Not that it's a bad film, there's just too much material, and it suffers in the editing room as a result.

Leonardo DiCaprio gives another one of his "I'm going to be intense and I'm going to haul ass all over the globe to track down the bad guys" performances reminiscent of Catch Me If You Can and The Beach. This movie is a political thriller with a message, and the message is mostly conveyed by DiCaprio's character through monotonic, stoic dialogue-driven scenes.

The plot revolves around diamonds in Sierra Leone, and the exploitation and genocide caused by the diamond trade. It's an important topic, and one that's obviously quite relevant given current world events- but I think this story tries to cover too much ground, and as a result the characters are a bit shallow. It's hard to become too invested in any of them.

This film was also reminiscent of another political thriller with a message, Hotel Rwanda. That film succeeded where this one fails in my opinion, because the characters in that film were more engaging and the story more focused.

Still, this is an important film that raises awareness for an important issue, and it's worth seeing for that reason alone. Just don't expect a tightly-woven thriller in the same vein as something like Syriana.

Although this film adaptation of the novel by Walter Tevis, The Hustler, starring Paul Newman as "Fast" Eddie Felson, suffers from a somewhat overdrawn and unrealistic ending, it is still a great film.

The story is based on the relentless pursuit by Felson of an uncatchable mark, performed in stark contrast to the seemingly carefree maneuvering of the mark, "The Man," played by Jackie Gleason.

During the course of the film, we see Felson challenged by The Man who sees in Felson a kindred spirit, and in their game the former takes great pleasure in defeating the talent and ego of the latter. Perhaps The Man enjoys seeing himself in the mirror of Felson, or what he once was, or perhaps he enjoys the youth and over-confidence of Felson, all of which is spelled out for the audience in nearly naked terms by Ms. Bernstein, who seems to have no other function in the film than to spell this out.

The tension of the film is driven by the contests of skill between Felson and The Man, interrupted only by the occasional dating sequence with Mona, played by Piper Laurie, or Felson's brother, Lester, convincingly played by Myron McCormick.

At the end of his rope, Felson takes on The Man -- the original fast dealer -- and is beaten according to the terms of their contract. Feelson, broke, owes The Man one hundred dollars for every cent he has in the world, and The Man, kindly, suggests that Feelson give him a call when he earns the money to pay him.

We next see Feelson in a small room garbed in monk's robes. He has earned enough money playing small time games in the local neighborhood to pay his debt to The Man. He calls The Man, and surprisingly The Man answers the phone himself, telling Feelson that he has gotten lucky and scored big -- he doesn't need the money anymore, and doesn't want to take it. He tells Feelson to "go out and find him," meaning The Man has retired, and wants only to play for the love of the game.

This, of course, is the explosion of realism in an otherwise very well done film. It is highly unlikely that The Man would have given up the chance to win the money owed to him, or that Feelson would have been able to retire if he had been forced to pay off his debt. But perhaps this explosion of realism at the end lends a

One of the most intriguing, challenging, and thought-provoking films of 2011, "Incendies" is an ideal choice for audiences who appreciate films that delve into the darker side of the human condition, as well as those who are looking for a unique and emotionally powerful cinematic experience.

The film, which is directed by Denis Villeneuve, tells the story of twins who are tasked with delivering the letter from their mother that reveals a shocking secret that has been hidden from them their entire lives. The film explores the themes of identity, family, and the repercussions of the past as it shapes the present and future.

The film's performances are top-notch, with Lubna Azabal giving a particularly powerful and moving performance as the twins' mother. Her portrayal is both heartbreaking and inspiring, and it is clear that she puts her entire being into the role.

The film's technical aspects are also impressive, with the cinematography and music helping to create a haunting and atmospheric tone that adds to the overall impact of the film.

"Incendies" is a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll. It is a film that challenges viewers to think about the world in a different way and to consider the impact of the past on the present and future. It is a film that is both thought-provoking and emotionally powerful, and it is sure to leave a lasting impression on all who see it.

Hart's War is a movie starring Bruce Willis, Colin Farrell, and Terrence Howard. It's about a trio of prisoners of war who are officers and kept in generally good conditions by the Germans. However, an offer comes for one of them to collaborate with the Germans, and this creates a crisis of conscience and ethics within the trio.
The movie is pretty good. The acting is first rate. I don't think any of the three leads are really given the opportunity to shine, but they are all solid. The story is a little bit predictable. There aren't a lot of surprises, but for a movie with a relatively simple premise, that's not so bad. I think the movie does a good job of showing the pressures on the trio and showing the audience what it is they value and why. It's not the most exciting movie, but it's definitely worth a watch.

The greatest flaw of "La La Land" is it takes two wildly different movies and smushes them together for no logical reason. Why did the writers, who I'm assuming are desperate for people to like this film, think it would be a good idea to shoehorn a secondary storyline that has nothing to do with the couple? It's obvious by the end that it's meant to be a bittersweet ending, and I'm okay with that. The singing and dancing numbers are very entertaining and well-done, and the actors have undeniable chemistry. The failures of the script and story outweigh those strengths, and I couldn't get past how poorly written the second act is. There's no reason for Mia and Sebastian to break up other than the writers needing a way to stretch the runtime. Even then, they could've padded the first act a little more and had the same effect. Too bad, because the direction and performances are excellent. It just needed a more focused script.

Although it suffers in comparison to it's [sic] predecessor, The Godfather: Part III is still one of the greatest sequels ever made, and deserves it's [sic] place as the second installment in perhaps the greatest trilogy in movie history.

The film achieves the impossible by making you root for Michael Corleone, even more than you did in the first film, while simultaneously making you hate him. It's a credit to the acting talents of Robert Duvall, who manages to make Michael seem both heroic and despicable at the same time.

The story is a effective [sic] sequel that expands on the first film, and explains away some of it's [sic] loose ends. The film is a bit slower than it's [sic] predecessor, but that doesn't stop it from being an engrossing, powerful, and thought provoking experience.

The cast is superb, and the acting is top notch. The film is worth seeing for the performances alone, and the fact that it's the second part of an epic story just makes it that much more enjoyable.

Yes, it suffers in comparison to the first film, but as a stand alone [sic] movie, it's [sic] still a great film. It deserves it's [sic] place as one of the greatest sequels of all time, and is a must see for any fan of the original.

'The Island' flops on every level, failing to introduce fresh enough ideas to save it from its derivative plot and its dullness."

Well that about sums it up. This is a film that is so dull and unoriginal that it gives you nothing to laugh at and very little to think about. I'm all for environmental messages, but this film is far too concerned with pushing its agenda and so ends up forgetting to be a film. Action-wise there is very little save for some standard shoot-outs, and logic-wise there is so much missing that you wonder how the producers ever got to the final cut.

That's not to say that there aren't some decent enough performances. Ewan McGregor and Scarlett Johansson manage to save some face by giving decent performances that at times manage to convince you that there is a good film here. At all other times they look as bored as the audience. Johansson seems to be trying out a Scottish accent as she takes on the role of the daughter of McGregor's character. Though it does slip occasionally it's not a bad effort and she manages to pull it off well enough. It's just a shame that the material they are working with is so weak.

The story concerns a group of people who are part of a community that has been hiding and preserving the last of the remaining animals of earth in an enclosure. However, the villains of the piece, led by Michael Clarke Duncan, want to get their hands on the enclosure and sell off the animals. Duncan manages to chew the scenery as the baddie, but it's all too predictable and dull.

There are so many things wrong with this film. The dialogue is poor, the story is non-existent and the action only serves to remind you how dull this film is. The only bright spot is the performances of McGregor and Johansson. If it wasn't for them this film would be so bad that you'd have to wonder whether the producers were taking the piss. As it is, it's just badly made and poorly thought out.

Charged by its pertinent subject matter, and propelled by Jordan Peele's confident feature debut, Get Out is a formidable entry in the horror genre. Peele weaves a plausible conspiracy theory into his screenplay, arguing that cosmetic alterations have diminished the humanity of an entire race of people. The filmmaker offers a stern rebuke to a society that encourages us to be passive observers, and he underscores his point with a horrific massacre that's unveiled in a startling sequence during the climax. It's in these moments that Get Out resonates most, when its biases are laid bare and its characters must confront the cruel absurdities of white supremacy.

Many of the film's most impressive attributes are owed to Daniel Kaluuya, who holds the screen with an effortless magnetism. He gives a finely tuned performance that walks a tightrope between humor and horror, and he's precisely the sort of compelling everyman every hero ought to be. All too often, we settle for male protagonists who are defined by their bravery or strength – traits that border on absurdity when we're asked to believe they've never before encountered a dangerous situation. Kaluuya is saved from this trap by his panicked expressions and occasional tremors, which confirm that Chris is mortal – and mortal peril is always more believable.

Kaluuya is also aided by a witty,economical script that infuses the film with incisive social commentary. Take, for example, the way in which the residents of the Armitage household speak in jargon that's barely coherent, rendering them nearly impossible to understand. It's the sort of pointed detail that indicates a perceptive mind at work, and it's clear from these moments that Peele has given considerable thought to the monsters he needs to portray. As such, when the film arrives at its fourth-wall-breaking finale, it takes on the qualities of a horror equivalent of Rashomon, with the truth dependent on one's own experiences. 

Get Out arrives at a pertinent moment in popular culture, as black horror stories are finally being given the platform they deserve. That Chris escapes the film with his humanity intact is, in itself, a small miracle – but it's also an indication that the worst has yet to come.

This movie is incredible. It's freakin long and meandering, but the attention to detail is astonishing. Every single scene serves a purpose, and even the minor characters have fully realized backstories and personalities. It's hilarious, and saddening, and thrilling, and maddening, and beautifully filmed. Yes, the soundtrack is great (though I disagree with Davis' assertion that it's the second best album ever made) but the DRASTIC tones and moods the Coens manage to evoke over the course of this film are what really make it work. Not many filmmakers have the courage or vision to make a film THIS risk-takingly slow. They deserve tremendous credit for that. Also, the fracking representations are very unsettling and effective. Overall, this is a tremendously rewarding film that offers rich rewards on multiple viewings. Very few films released in the last decade can boast that.
