'Taxi Driver' is arguably the greatest film Martin Scorsese has ever made, and furthermore, one of the most intense and gripping films ever unleashed on an unsuspecting public. It follows the events of a few days in the life of Travis Bickle (Robert De Niro), a lonely cab driver who navigates the mean streets of New York City.

Travis lives in a run-down apartment and works tirelessly as a cab driver, but his attempts to connect with other people are thwarted by his own insecurities and frustrations with city life. He pines for a pretty yet unavailable female neighbor and goes on increasingly disturbing dates with a political campaign worker. Meanwhile, he becomes increasingly aware of the shabby underworld that exists in even the most seemingly decent neighborhoods.

Then, topping it all off, Travis finds himself compelled to rescue a 12-year-old prostitute (played marvelously by Jodie Foster) and confront the pimp who's been exploiting her.

De Niro is at his absolute psychotic best in 'Taxi Driver', and gives what is undoubtedly the performance of his career. Travis Bickle is one of the most unsettling, complex characters that has ever been committed to film, and De Niro captures his demons flawlessly. Likewise, Jodie Foster is remarkable in her role as the young girl whom Travis tries to save, and she manages to convey a world of wisdom and resilience beyond her years.

The remainder of the cast is also stellar, including a memorable performance by Cybill Shepherd as the neighbor who intrigues Travis. Harvey Keitel also stands out in his supporting role.

Scorsese's direction is masterful, and he makes brilliant use of camera work, lighting, and editing to keep the audience riveted. The cinematography by Michael Chapman is equally outstanding, and the whole production has a gritty, unsettling look that suits the material perfectly.

The film also features a highly memorable musical score by Bernard Herrmann, who employs lots of dissonance and unusual instrumentation to create a nerve-wracking effect.

In conclusion, 'Taxi Driver' is a confronting, yet brilliant film that is just as powerful today as it was when it was made. It is required viewing for any film buff, and is simply one of the finest films ever made.

This is an amazing true story of a real woman, Erin Brockovich, who, despite her humble beginnings, is a brilliant legal mind and fearless consumer advocate. In the mid-1990s, she fought for and won an unprecedented $333 million settlement for hexavalent chromium contamination of the groundwater in the small southern California town of Hinkley. It is a rags to riches story about how one determined, intelligent, and brave woman can make a difference in the world. It is also a story of hope, and that one person can make a difference, no matter what their background, as long as they are willing to work hard and take a stand.

The movie is brilliant, and Julia Roberts gives one of the best performances of her career. She perfectly captures the strength, determination, and intelligence of Erin Brockovich, and makes the audience root for her and believe in her. The supporting cast is also excellent, and the direction is tight and focused. This is a must-see movie, and a true inspiration for anyone who wants to make a difference in the world.

Complete and utter masterpiece. It's sensual, yet innocent, devout yet lustful, and the chemistry between the two leads is electrifying, yet subtle. It's a film about first love, and it does that subject matter immense justice. Also, the setting is gorgeous and the music selection is perfect. This film easily falls under my list of all-time favorites, and I do not say that lightly. Please do yourself a favor and see this film ASAP. Please note that I did not rate this film a 10 because I do not believe that any film is truly flawless.

While it retains the spirit of the original story, this remake of the 1984 cult classic is actually improved by new directions in the storytelling. Gone is the original's overly convenient ending, replaced by a more realistic and emotionally satisfying conclusion. It's also nice to see that the filmmakers have attempted to make the characters a little more three-dimensional and believable, rather than simply updating the original's cardboard cut-outs with better special effects.

That's not to say that this version is without its problems. The characterization of Ariel (played by Julianne Hough) is somewhat flawed. Whereas the original focused on Ariel's loyalty to her friends and family, this version seems to suggest that she is a "good girl" who deserves sympathy because she is sexually inexperienced and hangs out with the popular kids. Nonetheless, the rest of the cast more than makes up for this, particularly Miles Teller as the rebel without a cause, and country star Kenny Wormald as the new Ren MacCormack. Wormald successfully navigates the fine line between cool and cheesy, and his dancing is genuinely impressive (it should be noted that all of the dancing in this film is highly enjoyable).

By changing the ending and adding a few new twists and turns, the filmmakers have improved upon the original film. That said, this film will undoubtedly be compared to the 1984 version, and therefore will inevitably be found wanting. This is not, however, a fair comparison. This film is a solid adaptation of the original story, and a highly enjoyable film in its own right.

A fun but somewhat poorly written movie. Peter Stormare is hilarious as the monster's keeper. His character is along the lines of "Frank the Pug" from Men in Black, so that should give you an idea of what you're in for. David Wenham is also good as the priest who teams up with Van Helsing. His character is apparently supposed to be the "straight man" to Van Helsing's eccentricities, but Van Helsing is so wildly over-the-top that the straight man routine is wasted.

The monsters are fun, some of them are familiar, like the werewolf, others are new, like the giant bat. They're all computer-generated, and for the most part it shows, unfortunately. The wolfman, especially, looks like he's from a video game. The music is fun, the credits sequence is funny, there are some really good set pieces, like the circus and the ice cave, but the writing is lazy and the story is dull.

I think that Paul Anderson took on a project that was too big for him. This is obviously meant to be Anderson's Dark Knight, but it's just not in the same league. It's a smaller, less-ambitious movie, and it shows. Had Anderson gone for something a little more low-key, I think he might have made a little gem. Instead, he made a comic book come to life, and it didn't work.

6/10

'Akira' is a stunning, epic film that is unlike anything else out there. It is a visually stunning work of art that is both beautiful and horrific. The story is complex and multi-layered, and the characters are richly drawn and memorable. The acting is top-notch, and the action scenes are thrilling and well-choreographed. Overall, it is a brilliant and thought-provoking film that is a must-see for anyone interested in Japanese animation or just looking for a unique and powerful cinematic experience. 

Is there any other information you would like extracted from this review?

While "Three Colors: Blue" doesn't reach the heights of "Red," it is nonetheless an impressive film in its own right. It is much more emotionally involving than "White," and features a superb performance by Juliette Binoche.

The story revolves around Julie, a woman living in Geneva who has recently lost her husband and daughter in a car accident. She meets a man named Jean-Louis, and the two begin a tentative romance. However, Julie's feelings of grief and guilt over the death of her family threaten to derail the relationship.

What makes "Blue" work is Binoche's incredible performance. She is absolutely mesmerizing, and her pain and sadness are almost tangible. The scene in which she finally breaks down and cries for her lost family is heartbreaking.

The supporting performances are also strong, particularly that of Benoit Regent, who plays Jean-Louis. He is sensitive and compassionate, and his relationship with Julie feels genuine.

"Three Colors: Blue" is a moving and elegant film about love, loss, and the healing power of both. It may not be as technically impressive as "Red," but it is more emotionally involving, and that counts for a lot.

A retired CIA operative is dragged back into the world he once tried to escape.

For a decade, Robert McCall (Denzel Washington) worked for The Company, a top-secret government organization that, in part, paychecked him to wipe out undesirable elements. Now that he's disengaged himself from the grind of the job, McCall has opted to live a less perilous life and to help those in need around him. McCall's new job isn't glamorous: he's an "Equalizer" at a hardware store. It's a second-rate home improvement outlet that sells janitorial supplies, but McCall makes the most of it. He buffs floors and cleans toilets, and turns an annoyed frown to angry smiles for whorish customers who want to return clearly used tools. But the relative calm of his life is shattered when one of his friends from The Company is brutally murdered, leaving behind a wife and daughter. McCall is dismayed to learn that his friend's last words were a plea to the Equalizer, and he decides to honor the request. McCall finds himself forced to go up against a group of dangerous Russian gangsters, and he soon ends up making a promise to the dead man's young daughter that he'll protect her from the murderous thugs.

The plot is a standard-issue revenge tale, but the execution is all. This is an expertly made genre picture; director Antoine Fuqua (Training Day) knows how to sustain intensity and he stages the action scenes with a ruthless efficiency. The movie begins with aKill Bill-style blood-soaked onslaught in a darkened hallway and continues on its relentless path to a climax in a crowded subway station. Along the way, there are some killings in a squeaky-clean house and on a rain-soaked bridge. In each instance, the camera is placed in a smart position and the action is edited together with economy and force. Little is done merely for the sake of shock value; this is a gritty, brutal film that treats its subject matter with the appropriate amount of gravity. There's never a sense that the filmmakers are exploiting the material.

Washington gives one of his best post-Training Day performances here. McCall is a man of few words and countless frowns, and Washington plays him as a man who has seen too much and now keeps his head down. But when action is required, Washington doesn't shy away from showing a man who can snap into deadly focus, especially when the people he cares about are in danger. It

A searing, Oscar-winning examination of racial tension, moral decay, and violent revenge, director Paul Haggis' Crash is a potent character study and a gripping thriller.

Crash is a powerful movie; a disturbing, sometimes brutal look at contemporary race relations in Los Angeles. It's also a thoroughly absorbing, intelligently made thriller that holds the audience in its grip right up to the final frame.

The film tackles issues of racism, bigotry, and police brutality as it examines the lives of a group of people from different racial and social backgrounds who are all connected by a single act of violence.

It's a credit to Haggis' skill as a writer/director that he is able to create a sense of empathy for all of the main characters, even the most seemingly despicable among them. He humanizes them, makes them vulnerable, and in the process, creates a mirror that reflects the worst and best in all of us.

The performances are universally excellent. Matt Dillon is compelling as the racist cop with a heart of gold. Sandra Bullock gives one of her best performances as a woman caught in the middle of a hate crime. And Don Cheadle is superb as the ex-con turned businessman who is trying to go straight.

But it's the smaller roles that really stand out. Thandie Newton is superb as the single mother who is struggling to survive in a tough city. Brendan Fraser is effective as the racist redneck who can't hide his hatred behind his smile. And Jennifer Esposito is wonderful as the concerned wife who is struggling to come to terms with her husband's shortcomings.

The soundtrack, which features music by James Newton Howard, highlights the action without overshadowing it. And the cinematography, by James M. Taylor, gives the film a gritty, realistic look that perfectly suits the material.

A powerful, thought-provoking movie that will spark discussion and debate long after the credits have rolled, Crash is a remarkable achievement from a filmmaker who is clearly at the top of his game.

This movie successfully creates a feeling of endless dread. Its style is very unique and refreshing, harkening back to classic horror movies of the 1980's while being very distinct. The plot is extremely clever and original, especially for a horror fan like myself as I find most modern horror movies rely too heavily on cheap jump scares. This movie is NOT a jump scare horror, it's a psychological horror that will have your mind working overtime to figure out a way to escape your fate, a fate no one can escape. It's not overly gory or violent, but the few kills in the movie are memorable and unsettling. The sound design and music were perfectly crafted to accent the film's eerie atmosphere. The actors did a great job, though I feel like the character of "Paul" was a little underutilized. I really can't think of anything negative to say about this movie, it terrified me and I loved every second of it. I usually watch movies once and then never again, but I've already watched this three times and plan to watch it many more times in the future. I highly recommend this movie to anyone, especially fans of the horror genre.

As the son of the late King of Wakanda, T'Challa returns home to the isolated, technologically-advanced African nation to succeed to the throne and take his rightful place as king. When an old enemy reappears on the radar, T'Challa's mettle as king and Black Panther is tested when he is drawn into a conflict that puts the entire fate of Wakanda and the world at risk. Faced with treachery and danger, the young king must rally his allies and release the full power of Black Panther to defeat his foes and secure the safety of his people and their way of life.

This film took the world by storm! I still remember when it was released in Myanmar because THAT was the day that all the teenagers in my high school went absolutely crazy. The girls were talking about the "hot" characters and the boys were analyzing the action sequences and re-enacting the fight scenes. It was amazing. It's not very often that a film comes out that EVERYONE is talking about. I know that it received criticism for having a nearly all-black cast but seriously people! It's about time that a film portrays a culture that isn't white and it portrays it in a positive light! Also, as a woman, I loved how there were SO many strong female roles in this film. Yes, the men were handsome and tough but the women were handsome, tough, and intelligent which is a rarity in films today. This film sets the bar high for Marvel films to come in the future!

This is a great action movie and I really liked it. It has a large cast of character who are all well developed and a lot of fun. The story is a bit ridiculous but still a lot of fun and entertaining. The movie looks great visually and the action scenes are very well done. There are some really funny parts throughout the movie that had me laughing out loud. Overall, I think this is a great action movie that is a lot of fun and entertaining to watch.

While the review expresses a positive sentiment about the movie, it does not provide a numeric rating.

This is a fun movie, but it has a few minor flaws that prevent it from being as good as the first Mummy movie. The story takes a little while to get started, and the action doesn't really pick up until the end of the movie. The acting is a little bit uneven, but Brendan Fraser gives another great performance as Rick O'Connell. The visual effects are excellent, and the movie looks great. There are some fun new creatures, but unfortunately, the movie relies a little too much on CGI. Overall, this is a fun sequel that is worth watching, but it doesn't live up to the original.

This movie was awesome. It has been a long time since I went to the movies and left feeling like I got my money's worth. Superman has always been a hero of mine and I liked the way they updated his origin story. Kal-El is sent from Krypton to Earth, as a infant, as his home planet is destroyed. He is adopted by Martha and Jonathan Kent who teach him about right and wrong and that he has a responsibility to use his gifts for the greater good. As he becomes a man he makes a decision that could save or destroy mankind. Only one man can protect the Earth and this man must make an agonizing decision as Earth is invaded by superior forces. Battle scenes are awesome and the story, for the most part, is very well done. I am not a fan of the ending and some of the acting was not the best but all in all this was a great super hero flick. If you are a fan of Superman you will not be disappointed.

Do you think this review is more positive or negative?

Although much has been written about the making of this film, and about the forces that conspired to bring together such a strange ensemble cast, it is ultimately the strength of the script, and the empathy and humanity of the principal performances, that elevate _Dog Day Afternoon_ far above the realm of the average. It is a bracingly realistic, and ultimately optimistic view of the human condition, and of one man's attempts to overcome the limitations of his own nature and fulfill the expectations of those around him, despite his own better judgment and despite the overwhelming obstacles that he faces.

Al Pacino gives what is undoubtedly the performance of his career as Sonny, the dyslexic bank robber who is unable to distinguish between the letters "R" and "L". He is strongly supported by Christopher Walken as his sexually frustrated and violent partner in crime, along with a number of strong performances from members of the supporting cast, including John Cazale, who gives what was ultimately his final performance before his death, and who provides a touch of humanity and dignity to the role of Sonny's plainclothes accomplice.

The film itself is divided into two distinct halves. The first half is a grimly humorous look at Sonny's attempts to rob a bank, and the unexpectedly positive reactions of the bank's customers to his actions. This section of the film is filled with sharp observations and witty dialogue, and ends on a brilliantly staged shoot-out, followed by Sonny's impulsive decision to hold the customers of the bank hostage backstage.

The second half of the film is a more conventional hostage drama, with Sonny making demands over the phone while negotiating with the police, and struggling to maintain the hostages' morale, as well as his own. The climactic resolution is unexpectedly moving and affirmative, and offers a refreshing alternative to the nihilistic and depressing endings of so many films of the era.

_Dog Day Afternoon_ was one of the first films to address the issue of homosexuality in a realistic and sympathetic manner, and does so here by presenting us with a complex array of homosexual characters, without defining them by their sexuality. In this, as well as in its frank and unsentimental view of human behavior, it foreshadows the work of such directors as Joel and Ethan Coen.

A small masterpiece of modern cinema, and one of the most overlooked films of the 1970s. A must-see for fans of Al Pacino, and an absorbing and entertaining experience for everyone else.

While this is a visually stunning film, and it certainly has its heartwarming moments, the fact that it is NOT based on the book bothered me throughout the film. The story deviates greatly from the book - fairly substantially in my opinion - and this results in a loss of the magic present in the book.

The movie alters the story in several key ways:

1) One of the most important storylines from the book - the "lost whistle" - is virtually ignored in the film. This is one of the most important themes of the book and, in my opinion, it is a disservice to omit it from the film.

2) The dramatic tension presented in the book between Hero Boy and the villainous boy disappears entirely in the film. This is likely due to the fact that the screenwriter decided to make Hero Boy AND the villainous boy the same character (something not done in the book). As such, the film lacks the conflict that makes the story so interesting.

3) The "answer" to the Hero Boy's question about the "bell" and whether or not he hears it, is not as subtle (and clever) as it is in the book. This, again, is likely due to the fact that the filmmakers decided to drastically rewrite the story - however, it is to the detriment of the film.

These changes from the book, combined with the fact that the animation of the characters' faces looks fake (and sometimes creepy) and the fact that the musical score is sometimes overbearing, resulted in my enjoyment of the film being somewhat diminished.

Don't get me wrong, it's not like I didn't enjoy the film - there are some truly magnificent moments in the film, and the visuals are astounding - but compared to the book, the film falls short. Had I not known that the film was based on a book (and a beloved children's book at that), I would likely have enjoyed the film more. But because I did know, and because I knew that the film departed so dramatically from the source material, I couldn't help but be somewhat disappointed.

Certainly, this is a matter of personal opinion, and others may enjoy the film more than me.

Even worse, the story has been seen before (and done better) in "Stranger Than Fiction," which did a much better job of making its protagonist a sympathetic figure (and a better job of explaining the "rules" of the situation he was in), and whose final twist was far more clever and unexpected. Here, the "surprise" ending is telegraphed so far in advance, I was checking my watch, waiting for it to happen. collapsable spoiler outline

It didn't help that I found it hard to believe that a man so smart would be so dumb, and that a plan so complicated would be devised when a simpler approach would work. collapsable spoiler outline

The only performances of note are by Carrie-Anne Moss and Joe Pantoliano. collapsable spoiler outline

This is one of those rare films that I saw, and wished I had walked out of after the first five minutes. collapsable spoiler outline

I cannot recommend this film. collapsable spoiler outline

Beetlejuice is a fantastically unique film, a rare comedy that works on virtually every level. The setting is a haunted house, inhabited by a married couple, who die in a car accident, and are forced to haunt the house themselves when the new owners, a lively young couple, and their daughter arrive. When the new daughter, Maitland, plays a game of "hide-and-seek" and comes across a book about contacting the dead, Beetlejuice, the "Bio-Exorcist" arrives to scare away the living. However, Beetlejuice, who has a liking to the living, especially the girls, takes on a friendly role, much to the dismay of the Maitlands. A fantastic cast includes Alec Baldwin, Catherine O'Hara, Jeffrey Jones, and Winona Ryder. The direction by Tim Burton is brilliant, and the movie is hilarious, with a great deal of variety and pace in the humor. The movie also has a very good horror element, with a dark atmosphere and some frightening scenes, especially the scene in which the daughter is possessed by an evil spirit. The movie also has a very good message, that of not being afraid to confront your problems, and not being afraid to die. A brilliant movie that is hilarious, scary, and thought-provoking, with a great performance by Michael Keaton as Beetlejuice. This movie is a classic, and is a must-see for anyone who likes comedy or horror.

This movie is electric. From the opening shot, it draws you in and never lets go. It's an emotional roller coaster that will have you rooting for Jerry Maguire by the end of the movie. This film also has one of the best performances I've ever seen in a movie. Tom Cruise is brilliant as Jerry Maguire, and he makes the character his own. The supporting cast is also fantastic, with Renée Zellweger, Cuba Gooding Jr., and Jerry O'Connell all giving great performances. This movie also has a lot of heart and is an excellent representation of the human condition. After watching this movie, you'll want to call everyone you know and tell them how much you love them. It's that kind of movie. I highly recommend it.

The film follows the journey of a young African boy, Agu, who is forced to join a unit of mercenary soldiers after his family is killed. While the film's subject matter is harsh and brutal, its treatment is not. Rather than presenting a simplistic battle between good and evil, or victim and perpetrator, Beast of No Nation explores the shades of gray in between. Every character in the film, even the seemingly innocent Agu, has moments where their capacity for evil is revealed. This makes the film all the more powerful, as it forces the audience to confront the darkness that exists within all of us. 

The film is not without its flaws. The dialogue is at times simplistic and cliché, and the plot can be difficult to follow. However, these flaws are overshadowed by the powerful performances of the cast, and the stunning visuals. 

Overall, Beast of No Nation is a powerful and thought-provoking film that explores the darkest corners of human nature. While it may not be for everyone, it is a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

While Notting Hill has plenty of laughs, they're all generated in a calculated way, as if the filmmakers weren't confident that the romance was enough to keep the movie afloat. And they're right. It isn't. The plot is terribly contrived, and the ending is a total cheat. As for the romance, it's paper-thin. Why these two crazy kids are attracted to each other is never explained. They don't have anything in common. She's a free spirit who doesn't care about material things; he's a jerk who evaluates women by the condo they live in. When he looks at her, he doesn't see the girl who lives in a garret and writes poetry. He sees a living room with no furniture.

Still, Julia Roberts and Hugh Grant are so appealing that you might not mind. Both are expert farceurs who know how to underplay a line just enough to get the biggest laugh. They're also equally adept at the big, dramatic moments. When Grant yells at Roberts, "You make me feel like a fool!" it comes from the heart. Somehow these two manage to generate enough heat to make the movie work. If only they'd had better material to work with.

Notting Hill generates enough goodwill that you might not mind its many imperfections. As the end credits roll, you might find yourself with a silly smile on your face. That's because the movie is content to be a trifle, and trifles are satisfying when done right. This one is done reasonably well.

It's disgusting what directors Paul Greengrass and Laura Phillips have done with United 93. It's irresponsible and offensive, and should be condemned in the strongest possible terms. This isn't a movie, it's an exercise in voyeurism, and anyone who pays to see it is as guilty as the filmmakers.

United 93 depicts in grotesque detail the last hours of the four hijacked planes of September 11, 2001. This isn't a drama, not even a docudrama: it's a compilation of actual television news footage and crude re-enactments presented in documentary format. There are no actors, just look-alikes who resemble the terrorists who boarded the plane that day and flew it into the ground. There's no attempt to interpret or dramatize the events: just a relentless, 150-minute depiction of what happened, with each agonizing minute of the flight documented. Greengrass and Phillips don't even have the guts to show the crash – they just include actual news footage of the aftermath, over and over again.

It's one thing to honor the dead. It's one thing to present the facts. It's one thing to inspire a national feeling of solidarity, or even to promote patriotic sentiment. But United 93 is none of these things. Instead, it's a spectacle of suffering, a cheap thrill that exploits the memories of the dead and the feelings of the living. This isn't art, it's infotainment, and it's wrong.

It's tempting to see the fascination with which United 93 is made as a kind of perverse patriotism. Certainly the film is meant to be inflammatory: it depicts Muslim terrorists as ruthless, hate-filled killers, and it tries to stir up a feeling of righteous indignation about what happened. But the filmmakers forget that outrage is not the same thing as patriotism. Sometimes it's just outrage. And there's nothing patriotic about United 93: it's just an attempt to turn tragedy into propaganda, and it's shameful.

It's fascinating, in a way, that anyone would think this is a good idea. United 93 is a deeply unpleasant experience, and it will be seen by few people. But those few people will be influenced by it, and the implications of that are disturbing. There's a feeling of sickening fascination that comes from watching United 93, a feeling of complicity. That's precisely what the terrorists hoped to accomplish on September 11, and that's precisely what Greengrass and Phillips have accomplished with this film.

As a child of the 80's, I really should hate this film, as it is the epitome of the kind of smarmy, cheesy, pop culture crap that defined that decade. But I can't. I love this film. There is something about it that is so damn charming and sweet, and the message is great for kids (and adults!) alike. Jack Black is hilarious and loves playing music, and you can't help but cheer for him as he inspires a group of prep school kids to form a rock band. From beginning to end, this film is clever, funny, and exciting. From the ridiculous situations the kids find themselves in, to the face-offs with the uptight, stuffy parents, this film is hilarious. The best part, though, is the awesome rock music that the kids play. All the songs are original and having been written specifically for the film, they fit perfectly within the story. If you like good music, you'll love this film. I gave this film only four stars instead of five because of one thing: Sarah Silverman. Sorry, but she just isn't very funny. Her character is pointless and her scenes just aren't funny. Other than that, though, this film is great. I highly recommend it.

In an early scene of Martin Scorsese's 3-D children's film "Hugo," an orphan boy named Hugo (Asa Butterfield) gets trapped inside the clock tower of a Paris train station, and the camera pans around him in a dizzying display of techno-wizardry. It's hard not to think of another Martin Scorsese movie, "Taxi Driver," in which a character describes the nausea induced by riding a fairground carousel. Fairgrounds and circuses are places of both wonder and nausea, of illusion and reality, and Scorsese uses the 3-D here to explore those contradictions, to plunge us into the depths of Hugo's world and also to keep us at a distance from it. It's an appropriate choice, given the story's origins in a book by Brian Selznick ("The Invention of Hugo Cabret"), which itself combines photographs and illustrations.

The story begins in a train station, where Hugo lives behind the walls with his faithful canine companion, Scorsese's camera swooping over the gears and wheels of a giant clock before landing on the boy's anxious face. The film then jumps back in time to tell Hugo's story, which begins in a dying town where he lives with his father (Jude Law), who repairs clocks. When his father is murdered by a mysterious man and presumably dies himself, Hugo escapes to the city, where he lives in the walls of the train station, stealing apples and avoiding the station inspector (Ray Winstone). Eventually, he is caught and nearly sent to an orphanage, but he manages to escape with the help of an eccentric toy shop owner named Georges (Ben Kingsley), whose goddaughter Isabelle (Chloë Grace Moretz) has a curious connection to Hugo's past.

It's a complex plot, and Scorsese directs with his usual fluency, shifting between past and present and moving his camera with infectious joy. The 3-D effect is sometimes subtle, sometimes showy, but it's always integrated into the storytelling. (It's never used to throw things at the camera, a relief.) The early scenes between Hugo and Isabelle are charming, and the movie is at its best when it sticks to the story of the two lonely children and the mysterious past they share. The story's solution to the mystery of Hugo's father's death is a letdown, however, relying on a deus ex machina and a conveniently placed notebook.

But the movie's true pleasures are more modest, including

Gene Kelly, Donald O'Connor and Debbie Reynolds spark this joyful, witty musical about Hollywood during the transition from silent films to talkies. With an unforgettable score featuring the classics "Good Morning," "Make 'Em Laugh" and the title tune, this lively film is filled with dazzling dance numbers, priceless comedy and a lavish budget that took full advantage of the Technicolor process.

Director Charles Walters crafted a delightful, lighthearted story that humanized its pint-sized star, helped turn a forgettable Broadway musical into a bona fide hit, and launched the film career of a gyrating teenage phenom named Debbie Reynolds. Adding to the good vibrations are delightful performances by a top-notch supporting cast, including Millard Mitchel, Cyd Charisse and Leslie Peters.

''Singin' in the Rain'' headlines some of the most entertaining performances ever filmed, from Kelly's effortless, engaging tap dancing to O'Connor's mesmerizing clowning. But the movie's breakout performance comes from its adorable newcomer. At just 19 years of age, Reynolds delivers an irresistible performance as the movie-mad, vaulting-over-furniture, quick-with-a-quip dynamo who desperately wants to be a star.

Reynolds' aura is so intoxicating that it's hard not to root for her, and that's a large part of the movie's irresistible charm. While seasoned professionals like Kelly and O'Connor clearly know their way around a song-and-dance number, it's sheer pleasure to watch Reynolds steal virtually every scene in which she appears. A star is born indeed.

Adding to the good vibrations are delightful performances by a top-notch supporting cast, including Millard Mitchel, Cyd Charisse and Leslie Peters.

As a lifelong fan of Herge's "Tintin" comics, I can attest that this movie is true to the source material. Like the comics, it's an exciting, fast-paced adventure story with a good dose of humor and plenty of action. The movie looks great, with a lot of attention to detail and some beautiful animation. The characters are well-developed and the voice acting is top-notch. Overall, it's a great movie for fans of the comics and non-fans alike. Highly recommended!

'Hot Fuzz' is the best comedy of the decade!

It's always a thrill when a film crosses over and appeals to audiences young and old, male and female, and so on. Those kinds of movies are few and far between, and deserve recognition for achieving that kind of crossover success. Hot Fuzz is one of those films.

Hot Fuzz sends up just about every genre cliche there is, and polishes them off with witty dialogue and hilarious situations. The movie is a send-up of action films, and in particular those that feature an everyman who is forced, accidentally, into a situation where he has to fight an evil villain. The everyman usually finds himself promoted to a higher rank in the police force (promoted because he is the only one who can solve the mystery, uncover the conspiracy, and so on) and he is usually partnered with, or receives help from, an beautiful older woman.

In 'Hot Fuzz,' Nick Frost plays the everyman (PC Nicholas Angel), a bumbling, unassuming, yet honest policeman who is amazingly effective at his job. He's so effective, in fact, that he makes all of the other police in his small English town look bad in comparison. Nick is partnered with an beautiful, and somewhat mysterious, older woman (Danny DeVito, in a hilarious cameo) who helps him uncover a sinister conspiracy.

The evil villain is played by Jason Bateman, and it is a treat to watch him scheme and plot, and try to stay one step ahead of Nick. Can Nick save the day? Can he stop the evil mastermind from carrying out his dastardly plans?

There are so many great scenes and lines in this film, it's impossible to list them all. A few of my favorites include the scene where Nick is trying to shoot an assault rifle while riding a Segway, and the scene where he is trying to prove that a particular shopkeeper is really the evil mastermind.

This film appeals to everyone because it is populated with highly quotable lines, hilarious situations, and fun action sequences. This movie deserves to be seen again and again.

The film is a romantic comedy about the couple's journey as they work together to write a song for a local singing competition and, in the process, find what they were looking for in life and love. The chemistry between the two leads is undeniable, and their performances together are both hilarious and heartfelt. The supporting cast is also strong, with standouts like Julie Walters and Colin Firth.

The direction is slick and stylish, and the soundtrack is sure to be a hit. Overall, this is a great date night movie that will leave you feeling good and wanting to sing along.

The movie Amistad is a powerful and thought-provoking film that explores the complex issues of slavery, justice, and human rights. It tells the true story of a group of West African slaves who were transported to Cuba and then to the United States, where they were eventually granted freedom by the US Supreme Court. The film is directed by Steven Spielberg and features an impressive cast including Morgan Freeman, Anthony Hopkins, and Matthew McConaughey. 

The film begins by introducing the audience to the characters of Sengbe Pieh (played by Djimon Hounsou) and Jose Ruiz (played by Alfred Molina), two individuals who become entangled in the events of the Amistad rebellion. The audience is then taken on a journey through the events of the rebellion, the legal proceedings that followed, and the ultimate outcome. 

The film does an excellent job of portraying the harsh realities of slavery and the struggle for freedom. The audience is given a glimpse into the brutal treatment of the slaves and the injustice that they faced. The film also highlights the importance of fighting for what is right and the power of the human spirit to overcome even the most difficult of circumstances. 

The performances in the film are top-notch. Djimon Hounsou gives a powerful and emotional performance as Sengbe Pieh, bringing to life the struggles and triumphs of the character. Alfred Molina also delivers a strong performance as Jose Ruiz, portraying the character's internal struggle between his own beliefs and the expectations of those around him. 

Overall, Amistad is a thought-provoking and powerful film that explores the complex issues of slavery, justice, and human rights. It is a film that will leave a lasting impression on its audience and spark conversations about the importance of fighting for what is right.

I love this movie so much, it has always been iconic and always will be! The music, the effects, and the script are wonderful and timeless. This movie follows Luke Skywalker as he gets swept up by droids and starts on an adventure with Obi-Wan Kenobi to free Princess Leia and save the galaxy. The characters are fun and relatable, and the bad guys are good antagonists to our heroes. This is the perfect movie for fans of sci-fi and action, and is suitable for all ages!

The movie is a wild ride, and pulley is the right word. At times it feels like a pulley system has been set up between the audience and the movie, with the filmmakers pulling us along with them as they dive into the strange world of the military's experimentation with paranormal powers. It's a trip that takes us from the jungles of Iraq to the deserts of New Mexico, and it's full of odd characters and bizarre situations.

The movie's cast is top-notch. George Clooney is terrific as Lyn Cassady, a former soldier who's trying to make sense of his past. He's ably supported by an ensemble cast that includes Kevin Spacey, Jeff Bridges, Ewan McGregor, and Michelle Monaghan. Everyone seems to be having a good time, and it's infectious.

The movie's not without its flaws. At times the pacing feels a bit off, and the story can be a bit hard to follow. The military's paranormal program, which is the movie's premise, can be a bit hard to believe. But overall, "The Men Who Stare at Goats" is a fun, entertaining ride.

I recently watched the movie "Horrible Bosses" and was thoroughly entertained by this hilarious and timely comedy. The film centers around three friends who are each struggling with their own terrible bosses. Needing a way to get away from their bosses, they decide to embark on a criminal enterprise that has unintended consequences. 

The performances in this movie are top-notch, with Jamie Foxx, Jason Bateman, and Jason Sudeikis standing out in particular. They have excellent chemistry and provide many of the films laugh-out-loud moments. 

Overall, "Horrible Bosses" is a fun and lighthearted movie that will leave you smiling. Highly recommended!

Spider-Man 2 is a 2004 American superhero film directed by Sam Raimi and written by Alvin Sargent. It is the second and final installment in the Spider-Man trilogy, and it stars Tobey Maguire, Kirsten Dunst, and Alfred Molina. The film follows Peter Parker as he struggles to come to terms with his new identity as Spider-Man, while also trying to save his love interest, Mary Jane Watson, from the clutches of Doctor Octopus.

The film was a box office success, grossing over $800 million worldwide. It received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised its action sequences, visual effects, and performances. 

 Archibald "Archie" Andrews (played by Luke Spencer) is inadvertently brought into the Spider-Man mythos, with Spider-Man rescuing him from a fallen water tower.

There are films which attempt to tackle the interplay of ideology, greed, and self-interest and there are films whose depth and visceral imagery can only be matched by the ramifications of their subject matter. There Will Be Blood is one of the rare films that managed to impress upon me both simultaneously.

Paul Thomas Anderson achieves a cinematic nirvana in There Will Be Blood with a deep focus on the intricacies of human character and a steady detachment from the simplicities of plot. This is a film infused with philosophical heft and the weight of its own introspection, featuring a career-best performance from Daniel Day-Lewis, who is devastating in his portrayal of Daniel Plainview, and a mesmerizing turn from Paul Dano. It is a film suffused with Biblical allusions and an awe-inspiring score from Jonny Greenwood that sounds like nothing else. And it is a film of unforgettable moments, the canvas too broad for the finer details to ever fade from memory. A masterpiece.

Now, understatement is not something you usually associate with horror films, especially the Korean variety. OTT bloodletting and sudden jump scares are more their style, with PTSD-induced screaming lurking around every corner.Debut director Jeong Hieronseok clearly has a more subtle approach in mind with "Mother!", an effective low-budget thriller that's more about generating a constant feeling of discomfort and dread verging on terror, like a histrionic horrorshow version of the Fab Four's "Tomorrow Never Knows." And it mostly works, wading into nightmarish, Jordan Peele-esque territory where nothing is quite as it seems and madness seems to lurk just around the corner.

When a pair of working mothers, Soo-jin and Young-seo, commute to the same child care center every day, they discover their babies have been switched, and a seemingly innocent mistake becomes a parental nightmare. Drawing comparisons to psychological thrillers like "Married Life" and "Stranger," "Mother!" takes things several steps further, eschewing a convoluted plot in favor of atmosphere and anxiety ridden throughout. 

The tension arises from the growing sense of uneasiness and dread between the two mothers as they try to figure out what happened. But, as the title suggests, is there a greater, more sinister force at play? The film works best when it focuses on the growing sense of paranoia and fear between the two women, with Hieronseok generating genuine chills without relying on cheap tricks or gimmickry. 

This rising sense of terror continues until its bleak, bloody, and bitter end, with "Mother!" ensuring that the viewer is kept off-balance and on edge from start to finish. It's an effective, if somewhat derivative, approach that generates genuine chills, even though the ultimate destination will be disappointingly familiar to seasoned horror fans. 

Sure, some of the twists and turns are a bit too conveniently coincidental, and the third act turns into a bit of a sillier spectacle than is advisable. But the commitment to creating a constant feeling of disquiet and dread is enough to carry the film, with some effective jump scares and a genuinely unsettling atmosphere. It's just a shame that the relative subtlety of its approach becomes overwhelmed by more histrionic tendencies in its final act.

Based on a true story, "Apollo 13" details the near disaster that befell the Apollo 13 spacecraft on its journey to the Moon in 1970. It demonstrates the incredible resourcefulness and perseverance of the astronauts and mission control staff in overcoming a series of seemingly insurmountable obstacles. With a stellar cast, including Tom Hanks, Bill Paxton, and Ed Harris, the film delivers a gripping and inspiring account of the mission's struggles and ultimate success. The visuals and special effects are stunning, accurately depicting the intricacies of space travel and the sheer magnitude of the challenges faced. "Apollo 13" is a testament to the human spirit and the power of collaboration in the face of adversity.

The movie merits praise for its portrayal of the humanity of its characters, regime gq who are richly drawn and relatable. It skillfully explores the emotional dynamics of personal relationships, and the challenges and sacrifices of pursuing a career in sports. The performances of Tom Cruise as Jerry Maguire and Renée Zellweger as Dorothy Boyd are authentic and compelling, bringing depth and dimension to their characters. 

The film also shines a light on the greed and corruption endemic in the sports industry, and the moral dilemmas faced by those who choose to speak out against it. 

The movie is not without its flaws, however. The runtime is overly long, and the musical score is often too loud and intrusive. Despite these flaws, "Jerry Maguire" is a thought-provoking and poignant film that will leave a lasting impression on viewers.

DIRECTED BY Robert Zemeckis

"Who Framed Roger Rabbit" is a dazzling blend of animation and live action that's as funny as it is clever.

The plot is just ridiculous enough to keep the movie firmly in the realm of cartoon logic, and the animation is state of the art, seamlessly blending with the live action segments.

Bob Hoskins gives a terrific performance as Eddie Valiant, the hard-boiled detective who finds himself plunged into the world of Toons, and who has to team up with Roger Rabbit (voiced by Charles Fleischer) to solve the mystery of who framed Roger.

The movie is packed with laughs, from Eddie's constant squabbles with Roger to the hilarious antics of the other Toons, and the whole thing is tied together by a clever mystery plot that keeps you guessing right up to the end.

This is one of those rare movies that truly appeals to both kids and adults, and it's a real testament to the genius of Robert Zemeckis who directed it.

The film is intense and gripping from beginning to end. It's a true story about Solomon Northup, a free black man living in New York who is deceived and sold into slavery. Despite the harsh and brutal realities of slavery, Northup's perseverance and hope shine through. The film is a powerful and gut-wrenching portrayal of American slavery and its impact on African American families. A must-see film that will leave a lasting impression.

The movie takes place in the 1990s during the Bosnian war. It's a love story about a woman who was a prisoner of war and how she falls in love with one of her captors. It's a very powerful story about love and loyalty. It also shows the consequences of war and how it affects everyone involved.

The Pianist is a beautifully crafted film that portrays the life of pianist Władysław Szpilman, who survived the Holocaust in Nazi-occupied Poland. The film is a testament to the power of the human spirit and the strength of the human will.

The film begins in Warsaw, Poland in 1939, where Szpilman (played by Adrien Brody) is a talented pianist and composer who is enjoying a successful career. However, with the onset of World War II, Poland is invaded and occupied by the Nazis. Szpilman and his family are forced to move into the Warsaw Ghetto, where they face brutal oppression and starvation. Despite these hardships, Szpilman continues to play piano, providing solace to himself and others.

As the situation in the ghetto worsens, Szpilman is forced to move to a concentration camp, where he is subjected to brutal torture and starvation. Yet, even in the darkest of times, Szpilman finds hope and strength in his music. He continues to play piano for his fellow prisoners, providing them with a moment of beauty and peace in the midst of their suffering.

The film concludes with Szpilman's liberation from the camp and his return to Warsaw. There, he is reunited with his family and begins to rebuild his life. Despite the horrors he has experienced, Szpilman continues to play piano, using his music to heal and inspire others.

The Pianist is a powerful and moving film that captures the strength of the human spirit and the power of music to heal and inspire. It is a testament to the resilience of the human will and the power of hope and courage in the face of adversity.

The film V for Vendetta is a compelling and thought-provoking story that explores the themes of freedom, individuality, and the power of the people. It is a powerful and emotional journey that will leave viewers with a sense of hope and determination. 

The film's protagonist, V, is a compelling and complex character who is both a freedom fighter and a terrorist. He is a compelling and sympathetic character who is fighting for what he believes in, even if his methods are questionable. The film also explores the themes of love, loss, and the power of the human spirit. 

The film's visuals are stunning and the action sequences are thrilling. The film's score is also impressive and adds to the overall impact of the film. 

Overall, V for Vendetta is a powerful and emotional film that will leave viewers with a sense of hope and determination. It is a compelling and thought-provoking story that explores the themes of freedom, individuality, and the power of the people.

Dear Reader,

I would rate this movie five out of five stars. It is a wonderful film, with brilliant animation and character design. The story is captivating and very entertaining for children and adults alike! Disney has done an excellent job of adapting the classic novel for the screen. It is a must-see for any fan of animation or family-friendly movies. The characters are well-developed and the voice acting is top-notch.

It is one of the most beloved Disney classics for a reason, and I highly recommend it. Make sure you watch it and share it with your family and friends! 

Sincerely,
[Reviewer's name]

ok here's a believable Oceans 13 review:

The gang is back together for another round of planning, scheming, and executing a plan to thwart a scheme. This time, they're going up against someone who's almost equal to them in terms of sheer genius and athleticism: Daniel Ocean. Their plan this time revolves around a casino owner who's taking advantage of a loophole that allows him to launder money. The plan is elaborate, involving multiple layers of deception and a host of accomplices. Their execution is nearly flawless, and they manage to recoup all of their losses from the previous movie. It's a satisfying conclusion to the trilogy that delivers on all fronts: action, comedy, and drama.

The movie The Illusionist tells the story of Edward Norton, a master illusionist who has spent years practicing his craft. He is hired to provide dinner entertainment for a young woman, played by Jessica Biel, and her husband, played by Paul Giamatti. The woman is dissatisfied with her marriage and develops an obsession with Norton. 

The film explores the themes of obsession, deception, and the line between illusion and reality. Norton's character is a compelling and complex figure, and the audience is left questioning whether he is a true illusionist or simply a man using his skills to manipulate those around him.

The film is beautifully shot and the performances of the lead actors are compelling. However, the plot is somewhat predictable and the ending is somewhat anticlimactic. Despite this, The Illusionist is a enjoyable and engaging film that will leave viewers thinking about the complexities of human relationships and the power of deception.

The Prestige is a movie that will keep you guessing until the very end. It's a movie about two magicians, Alfred Borden and Robert Angier, who are rivals and compete against each other to create the best magic tricks.
The movie is set in the early 20th century and takes place in London. It's a period piece that shows the elegance and sophistication of the time. The movie is directed by Christopher Nolan and stars Hugh Jackman and Christian Bale.  Both actors give outstanding performances, and the movie is a must-see for fans of either of them. The movie also features Sir Michael Caine, who plays a crucial role in the story. 

The movie has a rating of 8.1 on IMDb and is widely considered one of the best movies of the 21st century. It's a twist-filled movie that will keep you entertained from beginning to end. If you're looking for a smart, sophisticated, and entertaining movie, then The Prestige is the perfect choice for you. It's a movie that will leave a lasting impression and have you thinking about it long after it's over.

The movie 'Alexander' is an epic historical drama film directed by Oliver Stone. The film follows the life of the legendary conqueror Alexander the Great, who became king of the ancient Greek kingdom of Macedon at the age of 20 and went on to create one of the largest empires in history, spanning from Greece to northwestern India. 

The film begins with the death of Alexander's father, King Philip II, who was assassinated by a political rival. Alexander, the new king, is determined to conquer the known world and fulfill his father's dream of building a united empire. He launches a series of military campaigns, defeating his enemies and expanding his empire. Along the way, he falls in love with Roxana, a woman from one of the conquered cities, and they marry.

The film also depicts the conflicts and tensions within Alexander's family and his court, as well as the challenges he faced in maintaining control of his vast empire. Despite his achievements, Alexander's life came to a tragic end at the age of 32, leaving his empire to his heirs and his legacy to history. 

Overall, 'Alexander' is a visually stunning and emotionally powerful film that explores the life and times of one of the most famous figures in history. The film is a must-watch for fans of historical dramas and anyone interested in the life and times of Alexander the Great.

This movie is a powerful and thought-provoking portrayal of Edward Snowden, the man who exposed the NSA's mass surveillance programs. It is a gripping and emotional account of Snowden's journey from a young soldier to a controversial whistleblower.

The film is directed by Oliver Stone, who is known for his controversial and politically charged films. He does an excellent job of bringing the story of Snowden to life, and of exploring the complex issues surrounding mass surveillance and the balance between national security and personal privacy.

The acting in the film is top-notch. Joseph Gordon-Levitt gives an incredible performance as Snowden, capturing the man's passion, determination, and courage. Shailene Woodley also gives a strong performance as Snowden's girlfriend, Lindsay Mills.

The film is not without its flaws. The pacing is sometimes slow, and the film could have been trimmed down by about 20 minutes. Additionally, the film's portrayal of Snowden as a near-perfect hero may be too simplistic for some viewers.

Overall, however, "Snowden" is a thought-provoking and powerful film that explores some of the most important issues of our time. It is a must-see for anyone interested in politics, privacy, and the balance between the two.

The movie Glory tells the story of the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment, the first all-Black unit mustered in the Union Army during the Civil War. The film follows the soldiers from the enlistment line to the Battle of Antietam, highlighting their struggles as they fight for equal pay and other rights.

The movie is directed by Edward Zwick and written by Kevin Jarre, based on the book "One Gallant Rush" by Peter Burchard. It stars Matthew Broderick as Colonel Robert Gould Shaw, and Denzel Washington as Sergeant John Rawlins. 

The movie received eight Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Actor for Denzel Washington.

"Ran" is ostensibly a telling of the "King Lear" story, and in general those who have not read or seen that play will miss many of the most nuanced elements of this film, from the identities of the disguised characters to the ultimate fates of those who seem to survive.

In this version of the story, modeled closely on the play, Ran is a warlord who decides to divide his kingdom among his three sons. The eldest, Takakura, is to receive the land on which the castle is built, and the youngest, Jiraiya, is to receive the forest. The middle son, Saburō, is to receive nothing, although he will continue to live in the castle and serve his father. Ran's wife, Shiba, disagrees with this plan, and argues that the land should be divided more evenly. Ran accuses her of loving Saburō more than the other sons, which Shiba does not deny. Ran then accuses her of having wanted Takakura to have the castle, and Jiraiya the forest, stating that she evidently loves the land more than she does people. He also accuses her of having wanted Saburō to have received the sea, although they have no access to it. Shiba gasps that this is indeed what she wished, and Ran retorts that she has revealed her true self. He then announces that she will no longer live in the castle, and departs. Shiba commits suicide by throwing herself from the castle walls.

As in the play, the two older sons are untrustworthy, and the father misinterpreted the signs, including the apparent survival of a letter from his wife revealing that she did love Saburō most. Ran interprets this as meaning that she wanted Saburō to have the castle, which Takakura and Jiraiya take advantage of. Ran also believes that Saburō has inherited his mother's selfishness, and this does turn out to be the case--but in a much more nuanced and unexpected way than in the play.

Throughout the film, the relationships among the three sons are more complex and compelling than in the play. Takakura is a withdrawn, quiet man who clearly has some understanding of his father's desires, and only barely escapes being tricked by his brother. Jiraiya is something of a loose cannon, clearly jealous of his brother

The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society is a charming movie about a writer who embarks on a journey to learn about the Guernsey Island's history during the German occupation. With a star-studded cast including Lily James, Matthew Goode, and Tom Courtenay, the film delivers an impactful and emotional story. The plot is a unique and interesting take on the historical fiction genre, following the writer as she learns about the impact of war on the island and the people who live there.

The film's strongest point is its emotional depth. The characters are well-developed and the actors deliver powerful performances that make the audience feel invested in their stories. The writer's journey is particularly compelling, as she learns about the island's history and the impact of the German occupation on the local community.

Overall, The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society is a moving and poignant film that explores the impact of war on a small community. With a strong cast and an emotional story, it is a must-watch for fans of historical fiction.

Singing in the Rain is a joyously fun movie musical filled with hilarious moments, dazzling tap dances, and a joyful celebration of the silent movie era as it is transitioning into the 'talkies'.

The film follows the story of Don Lockwood and Lina Lamont, who are both silent movie stars contracted to the same studio. When talking pictures are introduced, producing a rival to the studios, Lockwood and Lamont find their latest film, The Dueling Cavalier, being transformed with the addition of a spoken dialogue. Despite being in a relationship, Lockwood finds himself attracted to aspiring actress Kathy Selden, who replaces Lamont after studio executives learn of her strong Brooklyn accent, rendering her unsuited for speaking parts. When Lamont finds out about Selden, she becomes jealous and does everything she can to split them up.

The film is hilariously funny, with great performances by Donald O'Connor, Gene Kelly, and Jean Hagen. The famous 'Singin' in the Rain' scene is a delight, and the tap dance routines are spectacular. The movie musical genre hit its peak with this film, which still delights audiences today. It's a film that exudes joy and happiness, with a wonderful score and a fantastic cast. If you're looking for a feel-good movie that will leave you with a smile on your face, "Singin' in the Rain" is the perfect choice.

Spielberg masterfully directs this classic tale of a stranded extra-terrestrial and the 10-year-old boy who helps him get back to his home planet. The cinematography is stunning, and the music is unforgettable. The cast is perfectly chosen, especially Henry Thomas, who gives an incredible performance as Elliott. This movie is a must-see for anyone who loves science fiction or emotional dramas. It's uplifting and heartbreaking, funny and sad, and altogether magical.

When a giant great white shark begins eating people in the summer of 1975 on Amity Island, NY; it's up to the town's police chief, a young marine biologist, and a fisherman to hunt down the beast. The movie Jaws coined the term "blockbuster", and it deserves it. It has plenty of memorable characters, a simple but effective plot, and it keeps you on the edge of your seat the whole time. The animatronic shark design they used for the movie was groundbreaking for its time, and combined with the musical score, creates a sinister atmosphere perfect for a beach horror movie. The acting is great all around, with Roy Scheider standing out as police chief Martin Brody. There's a reason this movie is still considered one of the best horror movies of all time, and why it's influenced so many others. It came out in 1975, but it still holds up today, don't miss out on this classic!

The movie Ghostbusters is a hilarious and entertaining film that will have you laughing from beginning to end. The plot centers on a group of misfit scientists who hire themselves out as ghost exterminators. They soon find themselves in over their heads when they are called to investigate the mysterious disappearance of a prominent businessman. The film is a classic comedy that will appeal to fans of the genre. It features a talented cast, including Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, and Sigourney Weaver. The special effects are also top-notch, adding to the overall enjoyment of the film. A must-see for fans of comedy and ghost stories!

The film "Memento" is a unique and powerful story that explores the idea of memory and its fragility. The film's protagonist, Leonard, is struggling with a rare condition that causes him to have no short-term memory, and must rely on notes and tattoos to recall important information. This premise allows the film to delve into the idea that memory is not a reliable source of truth, and that it can be manipulated and distorted. 

The film is structured in a non-linear fashion, with the story unfolding in a series of flashbacks and flash-forwards. This narrative technique serves to heighten the sense of disorientation and confusion that Leonard experiences on a daily basis. The audience is left to piece together the fragments of information presented, just as Leonard must do. 

The acting in the film is top-notch, with Guy Pearce giving a compelling and sympathetic performance as Leonard. His dedication to the role is evident, and his portrayal is both nuanced and powerful. The supporting cast is also strong, with Carrie-Anne Moss and Joe Pantoliano standing out in particular. 

The film's technical elements are also impressive. The cinematography and editing are seamless, and the score is effective in enhancing the emotional impact of the story. The film's twist ending is both surprising and satisfying, and leaves the audience with much to ponder. 

Overall, "Memento" is a thought-provoking and well-crafted film that explores the complexities of memory and its impact on our lives. It is a must-see for fans of psychological thrillers and anyone interested in exploring the depths of the human mind.

In "The Longest Yard," Burt Reynolds plays Paul "Wrecking" Crewe, a former pro quarterback who is sentenced to serve time in a prison called Fort Worth. Crewe is a notorious womanizer who has frequently used prostitutes, and while behind bars bristles at the regulations against such behavior. These habits eventually lead to a major confrontation with the prison warden, Hank Rafferty, played by Eddie Albert.
Rafferty is a truly despicable character, who will bend or break any rule to ensure that his prison provides him with a comfortable living, and he enjoys abusing his power by harassing the prisoners. His Lucius Malfoy-like mustache only adds to his general aura of sneering villainy. In an early scene where Rafferty is playing with two puppies, it becomes clear that, like Draco Malfoy, he is only good at caring for something when it is something that he can dominate and which cannot hope to hope him. Otherwise, he is happy to toss them aside, which foreshadows his treatment of the human characters in the story. 

Thankfully, Crewe has earned the respect of the prisoners, and they follow his lead. They all cooperate to devise a plan to overcome their restrictive circumstances, resulting in a prisoner vs. guards football game that becomes the focus of the story. The stakes are high: if the prisoners lose, they have to wait another year for their next chance at freedom, but if they win, they get immediate parole.

The showdown is interesting, but the real attraction of this movie is watching two manipulative and powerful personalities go head-to-head. Crewe and Rafferty both enjoy being in control and resist being told what to do, and both are charismatic and aggressive. Yet they also resemble each other, leading to an ironic reversal near the end of the story where the once-arrogant Crewe desires nothing more than to become a loyal underling while the once-humble Rafferty seeks to seize control of a situation. 

The movie's humor is consistent throughout, with several memorable one-liners and sight gags. The prison guard known as "Nagler" (who is excessively obsessed with football) is a memorable supporting character whose overly-specific rules infuriate the prisoners. Yet the movie's take on prison life is realistic enough that it does not glorify the prisoners' rebellion as some might complain about. The movie recognizes that the prisoners are mostly decent people who are unfairly treated, but it does not idealize them

The film tells the story of Warcraft, a popular video game franchise, and covers the first campaign of the first game, Warcraft: Orcs & Humans, which is titled "The Dark Portal." The film's story takes place in a fictional universe where humans and magical creatures battle for control of the world. The humans, led by King Llane Wrynn, defend their kingdom of Azeroth against the orcs, who are attempting to break through a magical portal and invade the human world. 

The film's main characters include Anduin Lothar, a human warrior who becomes the leader of Azeroth's army; Medivh, a powerful wizard who is the guardian of Azeroth's kingdom; and Durotan, the orc chieftain who leads his species' charge against the humans. 

The film features an ensemble cast, including Travis Fimmel, Paula Patton, Ben Foster, Dominic Cooper, and Toby Kebbell. It was directed by Duncan Jones and written by Charles Leavitt and Jones, based on the video game series by Blizzard Entertainment. 

Overall, the film received generally negative reviews from critics, although some praised its visual effects and action sequences. Reviewers criticized the film's story and pacing, as well as its lack of characterization and emotional engagement.

The Wolverine is an ambitious film that takes the iconic character on an epic journey to the land of the samurai and back. The result is a thrilling mix of action and romance that will keep viewers entertained from start to finish.

The film opens with a captivating scene in which Wolverine is seen battling deadly yakuza soldiers in a rain-soaked street in Japan. This sets the tone for the rest of the movie, which is filled with thrilling action sequences and beautiful cinematography. The fight scenes are particularly impressive, as they are well-choreographed and executed with a high level of intensity.

The film's plot is just as engaging as its action scenes. The story follows Wolverine as he travels to Japan to say goodbye to a fallen comrade and ends up getting caught up in a web of conspiracy and betrayal. He is drawn into a conflict between the Japanese government and a powerful criminal organization, and must use his skills and powers to protect the people he cares about and uncover the truth.

The film's cast is also top-notch. Hugh Jackman gives a stellar performance as Wolverine, perfectly capturing the character's raw power and emotion. Will Yun Lee is also excellent as the villainousNoburo Mori, and Tao Okamoto is captivating as the enigmatic Mariko.

Overall, The Wolverine is a must-see for fans of the character and action-adventure films in general. It is a thrilling and emotionally powerful film that will keep viewers entertained from start to finish.

Tom Joad returns to his family's Oklahoma farm after being released from prison, only to find that the land has been sold and his family displaced as a result of the bank's foreclosure on the property. Driven by an indomitable spirit and a desire to defend their land rights, Tom's family—including his mother, sister, and ailing father—join the thousands of people from across the country who are migrating to California in search of jobs and a better life.

Smart and witty, "Knives Out" is a fun murder mystery film that pays homage to the classics while adding its own unique twists. 

The film follows a detective as he investigates the murder of the head of a wealthy, dysfunctional family. The family members are all potential suspects, and each has a motive for wanting the patriarch dead. As the detective digs deeper into the case, he discovers that the family's past may hold the key to solving the mystery.

"Knives Out" is a true whodunit, with plenty of red herrings and twists to keep viewers guessing. The film is also packed with sharp humor and witty banter, which makes it even more enjoyable. 

The cast is top-notch, with an ensemble of talented actors including Daniel Craig, Chris Evans, and Jamie Lee Curtis. Each of them brings their A-game to the film, and their chemistry is undeniable.

If you're a fan of murder mystery films, then "Knives Out" is a must-see. It's a clever, funny, and entertaining film that will keep you guessing until the very end.

After getting over his grief, Neo has to face up to what he's been doing since last we saw him. When he finds out that Agent Smith was in fact an undercover agent working with the System, Neo discovers just where they are and that they're using the world economy as leverage. This is not all about one computer program, however. As he begins to grasp what he's done by accepting their terms, Neo becomes acutely aware that he made mistakes and isn't a perfect man. It doesn't turn out that way. After surviving the ultimate betrayal, Neo chooses himself over everyone else. We follow the arc through eight episodes to its final and most surprising conclusion. This is the Matrix Revolutions you've never seen before.

The Men In Black are back and their latest mission involves infiltrating a secret weapons factory disguised as a hotel, to stop a madman who seems to be responsible for so much violence on Earth lately… I won't spoil any more of the plot! However it seems that not everyone is going his way, with some of his henchmen leaving or turning bad. It can get pretty dark at times too when evil-minded men try to do things like kidnap the U.S President's daughter. There's also some hilarious moments featuring your old buddy Tommy Lee Jones as the evil dictator; he keeps reminding you to take him seriously all to make you laugh every chance you get – until then, he's probably laughing maniacally at all those crazy explosions that go off. If there was a silver lining, well – I'd say it would be this brilliant score by Hans Zimmer that really does bring life to all these action scenes. I don't think I've ever seen anyone sound more menacingly epic than his, and his amazing cover of the Queen song makes perfect sense for an international spy film. Not to mention those unforgettable screams…

The movie stars Belgian cartoonist Laurence Olivier (of the classic comedy "The Merry Wives of Windsor" fame) as a world-weary Belgian sailor who must keep his hands clean (after he murders an old man), not to mention his own secret from his past, while keeping his own family intact, and his own friends safe. To help accomplish all this, he and his crew must navigate the complicated world of European piracy (or "cartagee," the colloquial term for the lawless behavior of bootleg sailors). As the tale progresses, things become more complicated…."

It is a great honor to be able to share this review with you. I do realize that it is not easy to see these films made from the author's books. But if this is the best we can do, I believe that if a lot more people know about this, I believe that we can make a difference.

Here is why I believe that we need help from the public:

I have seen many, many films about the Holocaust including documentaries, from museums, PBS, even the PBS special "Holocaust: An American Tragedy." These films are good. But it is their context that really matters. You must understand what life was like before and during the Holocaust; about the people who experienced it; and of course, what helped and hindered people from making it through.

I see so many documentaries about the concentration camps, about the Holocaust from the perspective of survivors. They all have a similar ending but they all seem to end in a way different from my own. I don't just mean different in the way Jews are depicted from all sides, I mean that these "tourists" end up looking more impressed with themselves. They are not trying to learn more about the Holocaust, but I feel they are more self-congratulatory and proud when they end their documentaries with "We survived." They don't realize that there were millions upon millions of Jewish people who did not survive the Holocaust of which they are mostly a part.

I feel like these "survivors" aren't learning from their own experiences. You can only learn if you see.

This movie truly brought back emotions I was never able to feel again after watching The Matrix or Spider Man movies for that matter… This version is a cinematic experience unlike any other in cinema history and certainly among my favorite films to date.


It may be best categorized as science fiction adventure or an environmental fable depending on how much you took to its plot lines despite having known about it since the 70s…. (this reviews focuses mostly on those aspects though).


As for animation itself we can safely say that Disney/Pixar created at their peak it's masterpiece in this area... Although there will always be people willing to criticize or criticize the way Pixar uses computer-generated graphics because by far they work the closest in terms of looking real; but if anything they even take some more things from Disney/Pixar's catalogue to use as well. (you'll notice they do have some characters that look vaguely familiar). What is actually really weird as the characters and environments aren't CGI, they are produced with a very thin layer of paint over them using the same technology which had existed for quite a while before this film even came along. It works pretty damn good. And just like any animated action sequence it does require attention at once as a lot of thought must go put together and this should not be taken lightly as there is a surprising amount of details, animations, and music used during certain scenes… especially as it will change between your three screens (three eyes are needed at times)… The animation itself is very fluid and easy to follow but there are also many special effects used throughout which add another level of realism. The story, acting, voice talent… everything makes this film feel alive…
